The story campaign is remarkably difficult due to the fact of how random the AI can be. Not even save states can help you out of ruts, because Murphy's Law is more prevalent in this game than it is in real life. Even on the lowest difficulty setting, the enemy AI will be downright stupid in the manner that they approach you, but once they're in position and they know where you are... You're as good as dead unless you rethink your approach. On the flipside, the campaign is entertaining when you get lucky and are surprised to see things go your way for once, but it's usually by the skin of your teeth. Most reasons people would buy this game is for the multiplayer and other mods made for it, but the campaign mode should only serve as a crash and burn tutorial. If you despise frusturation but love when a plan comes together, this game is for you. It's important to note that this is more a simulator than a game, where you can create your own missions/scenarios, be it online or single player.  P.S. There are no realistic ballistic characteristics among the ammo calibers in this game. Unless you score headshots all the time, every rifle/pistol does about the same damage to enemy AI. It could take anywhere from 3-5 landed shots to take someone down. Your best bet everytime is choosing a low recoil weapon where you're able to re-acquire your sight picture quickly after every shot. Or, any scoped rifle. So, any SMG on burst fire or accurate sniper rifles are your best friends around here.

Rating: 9/10  Brief Summary: ArmA 3 is an open-world military simulator. It is a first/third person shooter with drivable vehicles, but is considerably more realistic than games like CoD or Battlefield. For example, the firearms handling is probably the most realistic thing you'll see in any modern game. Projectiles behave like they do in real life; they travel in ballistic arcs, lose velocity as they travel through the air, and drift due to wind. Due to the sheer scale of the maps (270 km2 for the Altis map), and the realistic weapon handling, combat feels very different from your average shooter. Infantry usually engage from hundreds of meters away; tanks and helicopters may engage targets that are several kilometers away. Cover, concealment, and smart tactical positioning are the way to survive and win in ArmA 3, and there's much less of the close-range machinegun blasting that makes up a lot of the gameplay in other FPSs. The inventory system is a major improvement over previous Arma games. You now have weight based system, and you can pick up a backpack and load that up with gear as well. Weapon modding can now be done on the battlefield, allowing you to switch scopes, add/remove flashlights and lasers, and attach/detach silencers in the middle of battle.   Content: You can either play a single-player campaign, individual single player missions, or play multiplayer. The game also features a fully-functioning editor that allows the creation of missions, and also can be used to free roam the maps. The game in its current state contains two maps, the 270km2 Altis map and the 20km2 Stratis map. These maps are fully accessible, highly detailed, and have a hand-crafted high quality feel. They are both land and water maps; anyone with SCUBA gear or a submarine can dive to the bottom of the ocean, which is detailed as well. The game currently comes with three major factions, plus rebel and civilian factions. Each of the two major factions have a decent working set of infantrymen, firearms, tanks, artillery and assorted armored vehicles, though aerial vehicles are currently limited to helicopters. There is a third faction which is currently being filled out by free DLC from the developers.  PROs: Huge game maps, open world gameplay, and a unique videogame combat experience. The developers have historically been friendly to modders, and ArmA 3 is now integrated with Steam Workshop so that you can download user-created missions straight from the Workshop.  CONs: Buggy, engine is somewhat antiquated and not well optimized. Single player campaign is currently unfinished (1/3 is currently released), but is being updated with free DLC packs.

I had high hopes for Arma III with Dayz Epoch attempting to carry over to Arma III from Arma II. I was expecting improved performance with current hardware......Arma III is a slightly improved code that still basically is 10 years old. The game does not support multi core technology and depends on single CPU strength. I currently use a FX-8350 processor at 4.2 GHz. I can attempt to play with all the video settings on low (disabled) or Ultra and never obtain over 30fps inside a city (just strolling down the streets, no fighting, explosions ect.) My current GPU is rendered irrelevant as my CPU consistently reaches 80%-100% usage and chokes the game.   This game is poorly optimized and I will not be purchasing anything made by Bohemia Interactive again. I enjoyed Arma II (though the same CPU issues were present), but I Cannot believe $59.99 is charged for a game that was designed out of date.  Just want to add, outside of the optimization problems, the core game play is solid and several games modes are really fun.

Simulation isn’t the defining aspect of Arma. It’s scale.  The enormity of the map is the foundation for the experiences that distinguish Bohemia Interactive’s flagship franchise. It’s what makes radios, topographical maps, binoculars, and compasses practical equipment in an FPS. It’s what allows for kilometer-long headshots and coordinated convoy raids. It’s what makes using your eyes to spot hints of enemies--muzzle flashes, tracers, gunsmoke--as valuable as being a crack shot.  The scale of Arma 3 dwarfs everything in the genre, including Arma 2. Altis, a keyhole portion of which is seen in these screenshots, is a Mediterranean island-nation assembled from ruins, airports, coastal villages, solar power plants, military outposts, salt flats, and tank-friendly scrubland. It’s a variegated backyard for you to play war in, but what’s more significant is that Arma’s landscape finally has the technology it deserves.

The game itself is unlike the easy predecessor Arma 2. When you get shot your guy reacts to it and makes assaulting almost impossible. Not only that but when you run your guy will become fatigued and start to slow down, this makes traveling long distances a little more realistic. Weight plays a great factor in the game, the more weight the less stamina making you a nice slow easy target. The hoarding days are over, carrying and unrealistic amount of weight and being able to cross the map on foot will be a challenge. The best route for combat is to take cover and move up slowly, most players will find this as a disadvantage due to time consumption. Take gun recoil into your thoughts as you choose what weapon to use, sometimes a smaller caliber rifle will out match the light machine gun due to weapon recoil. Stances can be your best way to get a better look at an area. Because Arma 3 uses bullet penetration, a wall does not mean safety. Some structures primarily wood ones can be shot through making peaking through a window and ducking when being shot at not that safe anymore. Also take in mind your ammunition, when you reload the magazine is put in your inventory and replaced with another magazine. Unlike previous Arma 2 games when you move onto another mission during campaign you carry the exact same items as you did before. Meaning if you left one bullet in your magazine and reloaded, you still have a magazine on you with one bullet. Using all of the rounds in a clip is advised to save needed space. There are vest and rigs that you can scavenge from dead enemies, these usually have items inside them when you pick them up so remember to check your rig or vest often. Attachments are a very nice part of the game, being able to pick up a enemy weapon strip it of its attachments pick your gun back up and attach the attachments to your gun can make all the difference. Choosing between one more magazine and one more grenade can be a challenge test out grenades and see how accrete you are with them; remember that a grenade has to be thrown unless it is a grenade for a grenade launcher. This limits the area that you can throw it too; take in mind that the trees and bushes will stop a grenade from continuing on its mission. Vehicles are nice but not as hardened as Arma 2 vehicles, Ramming down fences and running sown signs are now more consequential. Take in mind that during the campaign a great portion is on foot, but vehicles do have their part in the campaign. Searching the inventory of a vehicle that you cannot drive can be very productive; some vehicles have a abundance of items that can help you. A note, that in your controls in presets there is an option called Arma 2, if you are coming from Arma 2 this would be a nice option for you but if you are not familiar with Arma 2 controls you can try to learn the default controls. Unlike Arma 2 when night time comes you better have night vision goggles if not there is no upping the gamma till you can see, (as of currently) the gamma might be changeable in the main menu. Take in the environment and learn the terrain because you are in for one heck of a ride my friends, welcome to Arma 3.

Want to sneak around in a camo suit and sabotage the enemy's base from afar? Want to drive into the enemy base with a tank, pockets loaded with explosives and heavy weaponry? Or do you just feel like transporting your allies to key strategic positions for today? Well, the good news is that in Arma 3, you can do all of that and more.  This game was designed to be a sandbox military simulator, and it is just that. The beauty of it, is that it's not locked to either small-scale fast-paced run and gun or massive scale 24-hour battles. It can be both those things, and everything in between due to fantastic modding and custom map-creation tools that every player has access to. I haven't taken much of a look at the campaign, but to be honest, the Arma series was never really created for its campaign. Multiplayer is excellent, graphics are excellent. What else is there to say? Just make sure you have a beast of a PC if you want to run it on ultra-high settings.

This game is so awesome, IMHO bohemia has outdone themselves. I have played a good deal of arma 2 and it was sweet. But this game takes all (hence my already 115 hours in it). BECTI is one of the best gamemodes I've ever played worth the price of admission just for that. Im really enjoying the SP campaign as well, has its glitches and bugs but thats just arma.   The modability of this platform is really the reason to get this or any other BI game. I realize some people think that it is lazinees on the developers part to rely on modders to make their game great, but to me the whole engine is just a modding platform and BI has been nice enough to not only give us a peek under the hood, they let modders rip it apart and put it back together. Very rare in this day and age.   Spoiler for long part on optimization   Now to the real question...optimization and how does it run, my specs are 8350 under water light oc 4.3 ghz, R9 290 also underwater, and 8gb of 1600 ram. Well I will say it runs a whole crapton better than arma 2 on my computer, my experience is mostly limited to dayz in arma 3, but I played a bit of breaking point and if I get on a good server I get a good steady 50-60 fps outside of cities and mostly maintain 30-40 fps in cities until a lot of action with dips to 25ish. In arma 2 I couldnt even manage 30-40 on the best of days. So its a much more enjoyable experience. Now obviously if you go intel you will have better overall fps, my brother has a 4670k and 290 and gets an average of 0-15 better fps than I do (may not sound like a lot but when hes getting 40 when I get 25 it sure does). I got my 8350 for free so I took it, it works a charm in almost every other game except this one. Considering for some wierd reason 25 fps is playable in this game (its really strange, I consider 45-50 to be minimum in other games) ill keep it. You will ahve to work a bit to make sure you have good ping to a server, and if you have bad fps try another server, you'll be surprised how much a good server helps, when playing SP becti or whole lotta altis I sit at around 38-45 once the ai get going. When me and my brother play he hosts and I can get 50-60 for the most part with dips still into the mid-high 20s. So yea find a good server and it will make a world of difference!     The features in this game honestly amaze me (BI takes the cake when it comes to ingenuity), sling loading is awesome, and not only can you shoot from vehicles but Helos with ramps you can open the ramp and shoot from it, so sweet. The advanced flight model while challenging to learn is a lotta of fun once you do. The marksman dlc is looking like it will be sweet, deployable bipods ought to be a real treat (even if they should've been in the game by now better late than never!)  Spoiler for dlc (I didnt realize these spoilers didnt colapse, but it helps to break up the wall of text)    Speaking of dlc, there is a lot of negative talk about it, Which I dont quite get. Bohemia makes a dlc offers every engine feature free, and asks money for a few helos. The fact that they dont want to split the MP playerbase is really a great step in the right direction IHMO. If you dont want the dlc just dont buy it and voila nothing happens you dont get kicked off of servers that use it. You still get the best parts of the dlc for free (which were definitely the most work to implement on BI's part Im sure)  Ill pick on one of the worst but most popular now: EA and BF4. I played that game so much and I enjoyed it my overall K/D spread is positve, and I could manage to get MVP most if not all games, so yea I enjoyed it. but I also hated it, there were so many issues and here is ea still ram dlc down our throats along with battlepacks and class shortcuts. Im no sheep so I refuse to buy the dlc, I wont support such a money grubbing company at all. But now because every server (that has any population of which there are few enough anyway) has mostly DLC maps, I cant even play talk about not only splitting up the mp player base, but kicking out players who dont want to buy the dlc.   In the oposite direction, I was riding along with a guy in his taru the other day couldnt fly it but thats ok. People who think that the helos give an unfair advantage need to think again the damn things arent even armed.     Over all this is one of the greatest games I have played, the visuals are stunning. If you can get over some of the annoyances that are arma (ie movemoent is a bit wonky, no jumping execpt with mods, dieing from falling like 10 ft and more!) this game shines. I mean theirs what? Like 30 firing postitions? The attention to detail is pretty great. With the main map (altis at 270 sq/km) never has combined ops met such a huge battlefield.

The majority of the time spent on this game is online. However, it is almost impossible to come accross good servers with good players these days (Asia/Oceania/Europe). Servers are generally running non-vanilla gamemodes. While this can be charming for others (and apparently it is), it is very irritating to me as it eliminates the seriousness during the gameplay. ArmA 3 was meant to be the most realistic, strategic battle simulation game on the market. Therefore, user expectations are usually high and how much of these expactations are met is a very controversial topic. When you play ArmA 3 with a good bunch of game-buddies this is the best game ever, but you will find the most idiotic insufficiencies even though it has been more than 2 years FYI !  CONS : -No secondary arms visible on holster (WTF?) -Explosions are quiet childish and unrealistic -You can't jump without mods -Death animations are funny -Gore is minimized as possible -Woundings are boringly simple -Most important objects are not modelled for the animations. For example, healing animation is basically self-injecting a syringe of adrenalin to the leg. Ermm.. There is no syringe. Have I mentioned the animation for healing other players ? Well, no need because it is also self-injection animation. Another example, reloading the rocket launchers. There is no rockets. How about that ? -Musics. -Everyone plays individually in multiplayer. There is no teaming up, this is mostly due to language barriers. But these can be and should be solved with visuals.  PROS: -Graphics. -The world. It is practically real. I have personally went to one of the maps (islands) that actually exists. Nature and environment is very very real. -Physics, sounds, dynamics, realism, weapons. Thumbs up. -Openness to development -Customizations -My high hopes and never-ending expectations

Arma 3 is an awesome game in my opinion. It caters to people who are interested in the miltary, tactical thinking, and simulators. It is much more than a fps game, it takes tactics, restraint, communication, being careful, and being calm. It has a hard learning curve to become an effective soldier, but thats the best part. There is bootcamp to learn the basics and campaign to learn tactics and how to shoot. I find even if I do not take a single shot, I still meet nice people and have a great time. Do not feel overwhelmed by the combat. There is a bunch of servers that are not veteran combat simulators like Altis Life and Epoch.   My first experience in an regular invade and annex server does not seem amazing. I met up with my squad and boarded a helicopter. The heli was shot down by enemy aa in a matter of seconds. next we took a jeep for some reason which was shot by a tank and blew up. We then were shot off quad bikes. Then crashed another heli. Finally we reached the combat area. Then we were hacked. Our heads were replaced with street cones or burlap bags. Then the hacker shut down the server. This did no matter because I was with the funniest and nicest people. We made jokes and laughed. It was just a great time.  I have made countless other memories like getting a colleteral with a sniper rifle, shooting 20 people in the matter of 5 minutes, and huddling in a 10mx10m chapel with 20 men hiding from an attack helicopter. Although people say Arma is boring and uneventful, if you have a decent amount of patcience, you will be rewarded with a great playing experience.

Buy it.    Hands down best military shooter i've played since BF1942. No arcade feeling on this one. You will get pinned down, shot in the legs, and be crawling for cover, and that's just from ai missions. Make use of your stances and peek around cover, make sure you dial in your sights to the right range and if that 50 cal starts turning on your position you better run.    Getting tired of being in the sh!t? Download some modded missions like wasteland or exile and start surviving! Watch out for bandits that will kill you for that canned catfood hiding in the desolate hills of a devastated world.    More of a sandbox make your own mission kinda player? Well go to the editor and spawn whatever you like on the map, hop in to preview and play with it, then save it and upload it to the community. Or you could just download one of the thousands others have already made.   This is an amazing sandbox shooter, with vehicle, bullet velocity, and damage realism. Definitely not run and gun and you won't run through a room shooting and knifing 5+ players here.    However every game has it's cons. There's a couple of bugs to watch out for that have been in the game since day 1, and don't seem to ever be getting fixed. Here are the big ones.  -You can break your legs on small falls, such as off the side of stairs more than a few feet high but its easy to avoid once you know. -Players can peek through walls (some anti-cheat fixes this) -Sometimes you get stuck floating on second floors, but all you have to do is prone or vault   So if you're thinking of getting a new military shooter, and you're tired of the BF4 or COD feeling, you should definitely give Arma 3 a shot.

Imagine this, your walking down a road going on a patrol with your friends and all the sudden a single shot rings out and your squad lead gets hit. Naturally you all run to cover but two more get hit before you can go prone, so you call out to the remaining squad members about how they are doing but you come under fire from the left flank killing everyone they took cover on the left side. So its just you and one friend left, against 5 possible contacts and a sniper. Seems like impossable odds? Well you are in the middle of a town and the cover you went into is a house in which your partner is in the other house so what you do is use hit and run tatics slowly killing them off until you get lucky and wipe off the flanking squad. Now all thats left is the sniper in which you know where he is because you saw his muzzle flash on his first shot. So you and your partner slowly move towards his position out side of town and you take aim, the first shot misses. Now he is alerted to your position and fires a single shot before you could kill him. He misses you, but hits your friend. Arma is a game where a single mistake, a mistake that can change you from the hunter to the prey. It could be even as small as forgetting to bring extra ammo to as major as not following a patrol pattern. Situational awarness is probally the best skill you can have in arma, of course being able to hit things is as well. The only reason why this game is still 40 bucks is not because of the dlc's and the vanilla content (Don't get me wrong i've spent 90 hours on vanilla but thats about it) but mainly because of the amazing modding community.

For TL:DR, scroll to bottom for summary.  Arma 3 is a Military Simulator (milsim) which gives a focus on teamplay. Started as an Early Access title (one of the few Early Access titles that actually worked), gamers were able to submit feedback reports to the Arma 3 developers on a feedback website. This existed throughout Alpha and Beta phase until its full release. Because of this, the player base provided a lot of great feedback to the developer teams which ended up giving us a game much better than Arma 2. The player movement feels more fluid, the graphics are more clear, the world interactions and combat are better. Arma 3 is a little different in style from Arma 2, because it is more focused on a near-future war between NATO and CSAT (CSAT is a fictional Middle Eastern/Asian alliance).   Even after the game was launched, constant improvements have been made to the game, such as the introduction of the Marksmen update, which incorporated weapon bracing on world objects, the use of bipods on sniper weapons, vehicle-based turn-in/turn-out shooting (using a gun in a passenger vehicle) and the Helicopters update, which added a better physics model to helicopter flight and dynamics. These were released with DLC; but the actual mechanics were given to all players, which in itself: is generous of Bohemia to do so. Arma 3 just had a visuals update, which fixed the ugly water graphics glitch where water would animate above ocean level up terrain + other little changes here and there. With this aside, Arma 3 is a pretty solid game; but does have some steeper system requirements: thus may not work for everyone.  Arma 3 incorporates a coordinate system that real militaries use, squads, squad formations, identification of hostiles and movement is all a familiar thing to anyone who may have experienced time in the armed forces (I have not, but I know people who have and they were impressed). The game is not for your typical Call of duty or Rainbow Six or Battlefield type of player, the gunfights are much more challenging. In combat, you may have to zero in your sights to shoot down enemies from longer (or shorter) distances. The ballistics model in the game can be demonstrated clearly with the Virtual Arsenal/Virtual Training where the traces of each round can be viewed. Body armor matters in this game, as using lower-powered ammo will not cause as much damage (if none) to a target, thus forcing you to aim elsewhere or use a stronger gun. What is even cooler, is that if you shoot a enemy target far away with a lower-powered gun, the bullet velocity eventually slows down to the point where damage isn't as high as it would have been out the muzzle.   Vehicles have hitboxes; meaning that if a RPG strikes the side of an armored vehicle like an APC; the wheels/treads will likely take more damage than the vehicle's hull (unless a well-placed RPG shot gets in a weak spot). Grenades are useful, but not against armored targets (yes, frag grenades are almost completely useless against a 60 ton steel tank.) This encourages you to coordinate attacks on enemy targets, calling in airstrikes, specialists and other well-equipped units to deal with tougher hostiles, while your standard issue assault rifle will do just fine for infantry combat. The multiplayer in Arma 3 is the best, because you are around live players doing missions together which can be quite fun, even though there is a learning curve; it is well-rewarding when a mission succeeds and everyone makes it back alive. Arma has no shortage of tactical combat and planning. Keep in mind, this game isn't for everyone; simply because you don't usually join a server and have instant action all the time, it is more of a game of patience and finesse (or BLOW UP EVERYTHING if it is required).   In addition to the large maps and coordinated gameplay, this game has a rather good modding community with great mods coming out all the time. The game recently got a 3d mission editor which allows the use of a camera for much more precise object placement and better visualization. The game comprises of a nice scripting layer, which you can write your own custom scripts that can be executed in the game to present new operations. Modders have been able to make dynamic campaigns that are randomly generated and large scale. The modding capabilities are great, I have a USS Nimitz mod with an F-18, so I can do full carrier take-offs and landings, as well as in-flight refuel. Because I love to fly, a lot of my time is in the cockpit of a jet doing Combat Air Patrol (CAP) or Close Air Support (CAS) for ground units. Other times, I act as a transport pilot; but on many occassions I have done frontline ground assaults with a full squad armed with an SCAR CQB, RGO grenades and full body armor. This missions get hot sometimes, other times they are a walk in the park.   Arma 3 also has some diving units and missions; which are SEAL-level of awesome. You can board a small submarine and sneak up on the coast of an island, then walk inland and plant explosives on a enemy communications listening post. It is quite fun, and is even better when you do it at night. The AI in Arma 3 is much better than Arma 2, and the game has come a long way; I can vouch for that being a Early-Access Alpha and Beta contributor. Overall, if you are a fan of games which offer depth and a learning curve, Arma 3 is for you. The plus side of getting good at Arma 3, is you can turn your head back to those COD/BF/RS players and say: 'You got nothing on me.' If it isn't for that, it is just a great and enjoyable military simulator. If anyone has played Operation Flashpoint: Cold War Crisis; this is basically a modern reincarnation of that.   Summary -   Pros: + Realistic warfare. + Challenging combat. + Team oriented gameplay. + Great modding support and community. + High replay value. + Land, Air and Sea combat. + Good assortment of weaponry, vehicles and units. + Easy and intuitive in-game editor. + Strictly a skill-based experience. + The IP owners legally authorize modders to port Arma 1 and 2 content. + Unit customization and a virtual arsenal for loadout editing and saving.   Mixed: = Some small DLC came out, but the developers did include the mechanics for free for non-DLC owners.  Cons: - Some areas are poorly optimized, thus presenting sometimes poor performance. - Not enough naval warfare. - FOV in some vehicles without optics can appear zoomed in.  I recommend.

SINGLEPLAYER-ONLY REVIEW. I haven’t touched multiplayer at all.    ArmA  is the type of game the GameSpots or IGNs of the world might give a 6 or 7 out of 10 because of big technical flaws, but offers something special that some might enjoy as much as a 9/10 game, kind of like Mirror’s Edge. Among military shooters it’s ambitious to the point of spectacularly falling on its face at some points and achieving equally spectacular feats at other points. It’s one of those games from which I wish other developers borrowed some ideas and gave them more polish, but I keep playing this one because no one else is making anything quite like it.  I’m mainly writing this review for anyone who hasn’t been exposed to Bohemia Interactive’s previous military simulators in the  ArmA  and  Operation Flashpoint  series, and a lot of what I’m about to write really applies to all these games.    ArmA  is the kind of game where missions simply give players objectives but no linear paths to completing them, usually commanding an AI squad. If you’re under an AI commander or squad leader, it’ll feed you dynamic objectives based on its own objectives and in reaction to what’s actually happening. For many this might be a first clue towards how ambitious and unscripted the AI in  ArmA  is. Another is how characters dynamically call out actual enemy positions in a sort of robot voice, indicating distance and direction. You can reload a combat encounter 20 times and get 20 different battles.  These battles can rage across miles in an open world that easily dwarfs games like  Skyrim  and is probably far larger than  Grand Theft Auto V . In includes forests that look as big as actual forests, and dozens of towns where you can open every door in every building. It’s not a matter of content, it’s this big to create a proper stage for combined-arms combat simultaneously incorporating full-scale infantry, tank, and air battles.  That scale makes  ArmA  feel nothing like conventional shooters in terms of pace or tactics. It isn’t a game about constant combat, it’s a game where you might spend 15 minutes driving or marching your squad across peaceful landscapes until a bullet suddenly whizzes past your head and instantly transforms the scene. I personally think it makes for a good sense of contrast. You’ll also rarely fight enemies less than 150 meters away.  If you’re like me and are mainly in it for the singleplayer experience, let me tell you I got much more out of modded content than Bohemia’s actual campaign. It’s not terrible but it also rarely makes use of the game’s core strengths. The campaign is split into three parts. In the first you’re a grunt following orders in what feel like slightly more dynamic Call of Duty battles. The middle act is the campaign at its best. In it you lead a small AI squad in guerrilla attacks and are given much more legroom in how you handle objectives. In-between missions this act let’s you traverse Altis and complete side objectives, which can end up being really cool demonstrations of  ArmA's  elements. Going on a quiet road trip under the night sky to ultimately plan your own assault in a pitch black forest or an urban mission in the city lights just isn’t something you can get anywhere else right now. The final third of the campaign has you leading larger groups into larger battles, but not with the same degree of freedom.  ArmA 3's  final mission, depending on story choices, is a neat and challenging take on open-world survival gameplay.  The uneven campaign is ultimately forgotten in the face of the mountains of fan-made mission and even campaigns. Many of them understand and play to the appeal of  ArmA's  dynamic open-world action. Some do this on a smaller scale using chunks of the world map (or custom maps), while others try to create grand adventures across the whole thing where almost all decisions are up to the player. There is easily enough good fan content for  ArmA 3  now to eclipse most typical shooter campaigns from a content standpoint. That doesn’t even mention the custom maps, units, weapons, and vehicles modders constantly churn out. The editor itself is fairly easy to grasp considering how obtuse the actual game can be. I’ve often had fun simply planting a jeep or helicopter in a map and using that to explore it, or setting up my own battles between AI characters.  That brings me to the first possible sticking point for those who try to step into Bohemia games. While it’s progressed over the years,  ArmA  has an interface that feels like it was designed around 90’s PC gaming principles from before console developers started to streamline things. The default control scheme uses basically the whole keyboard (and is designed to accommodate the lack of a mouse). The squad command interface relies completely on the function and number keys without using any mouse interface except the scroll wheel. The inventory system is a whole other can of worms. The fact that characters and even vehicles have inventory space is genius if you ask me, but the implementation is confusing at first and awkward once you get used to it.  ArmA  is everything about PC simulators that both intrigued and scared away console users in previous decades, but applied to today’s technology.   If you’re still willing to stick with it for the gameplay opportunities I described earlier in this review, you’ll also have to forgive Bohemia for not having EA or Ubisoft money despite doing things far more ambitious than either. That means animations that are downright robotic compared to Uncharted, PS1-era voice acting, and massive glitches despite years of bug squashing. To be honest the vanilla AI still doesn’t really know how to navigate indoors. AI driving? Good God.   Then you’ve got  ArmA's  overall performance. It’s hell on CPUs, for both reasonable and bad reasons. This is a game that will calculate the trajectories of bullets 20 miles away from you and the decisions of every character firing them. On the other hand,  ArmA 3  mostly uses only one or two CPU threads, so raw clock speed is more important here than cores. This game probably benefits more than most others from CPU overclocking. On my stock i5-4670k at 3.5GHz it’s not unusual to have framerates in the 20’s for minutes on end. Bohemia is slowly trying to bring this game and  DayZ  into modern DirectX versions but it’s been a slow process.  Still, you have to give Bohemia credit for adding to and tweaking the game as much as it has been for three years. Since launch there have been massive changes to the way weapons work, the lighting system, and the audio. With the  Apex  expansion coming soon, it doesn’t look like Bohemia’s gonna stop developing this game for a while.   ArmA 3  is one of my favorite games to play right now, but that’s because I’m so entranced by the scale and freedom of its missions that I’m willing to put up with an incredibly clumsy user experience. If the standard COD or BF experience completely satisfies you and you’re just looking to see how  ArmA  competes then you’ll probably find it to be a poor-man’s version from a bunch of weirdos in the Czech Republic. Anyone willing to dive into obtuse command interfaces to reach the expanded possibilities within, piles of mods to continually customize the game, and toy around with a hardcore sandbox, will find a quintessential modern example of PC simulation gaming.

My first A3L experience:  *Le me speeding down the street in my car when suddenly a wild police officer appears from alley* '10-20 on the 10-72; Kavala Square.' He says into his radio, his sirens wailing and lights flickering. I take a sharp turn to the left, making the officer fly 20 feet into the sky, his hatchback giving its final, saddening yell before plummeting to the ground, exploding and killing the officer on impact.  I turn around, a Hunter and two SUVs headed my way: I must escape quickly! I held shift, accelerating my car by 10km/h. I proceeded down the road that I originally aimed for, soon turning into a dark alley to avoid contact with the law-enforcement.   'NEEEEEEOW!'  A series of blue lights and sirens sounded past my location. I was safe; or at least I thought so. Before I could realise, a PD helicopter was patrolling the skies, soon discovering and announcing my location. As its beam of light beaconed at me, I reversed from the tight space, and sped to the town centre - Kavala square.   Disobeying the speeding limit, I held my finger firmly on the shift key, knowing that if I let go I'd be trampled and macerated by the Hunters that persued me. Realising that the whole of Kavala PD was now shadowing me, I lead them to their unexpected deaths: attempting to de-sync ram those like the detective I eliminated before. It wasn't long until they raced down the street - I stuck the front of my vehicle out of the gap, sending the impenetrable Hunter to its destined death.  Untouched, my car remained in pristine condition, however I was still in pursuit. Locked onto me, the chopper hovered above, revealing my position. Intimidated, I abandoned my Offroad and scrapped my clothes, sprinting to the suit-store. I purchased a cheap hobo-outfit and ran back to my car, only to realise it is now under the jurisdiction of the cops as they formed a road-block, defending the crime-scene.   Attempting to explain to the officers that the vehicle belongs to 'my friend', they stated that I should leave. In protest, I stole (however I do not think of it as stealing, rather borrowing my own ride) the OffRoad, detonating two police cars and myself during the process.  TLDR: I rammed some cops, abandoned the car, changed clothes, stole the vehicle back and we all exploded.

So i got this Simulator 2 days ago, i am an ArmA Veteran playing since 2003 (back when it was still called Operation Flashpoint) and from that point i can but say that ArmA3 takes all my memories of those past days and brings them back in a polished and modern form. Just starting and playing the campaign which incorporates only the best aspects of all previous releases and campaigns starting from CWC down to Red Harvest in ArmA2, we have: 1. Fast paced action as in CWC - You usually start in the action or closeby, no longer do you need to relocate over miles to get into your AO 2. A small unit gameplay as was featured in the Red Hammer campaign. 3. Weapons and Magazines carry over to next mission, as seen in Resistance 4. Campaign with optional sidemissions, as seen in Armed Assault and Queens Gambit 5. Sidemissions may include long range scouting with dynamic elements, as created by the community and similarily featured in the Red Harvest campaign  The inventory system has been completly overhauled and provides a lot more possibilities than previous releases, instead of slots (which are still kind of there) you now have a weight limit similar to what ACE mod previously suggested. Pack a lot of stuff and you will drain stamina more quickly, on the other hand don't carry much stuff or heavy armor around with you and you can run for miles - but a single bullet can put you down and you risk running out of ammo.  Movement controls have been streamlined to provide a more simple and user-friendly experience akin to ArmA CWA, and in contrast to the 2 previous releases. You have a lot of options, though you do not need to map everything.  Then we have the new battlefield that was added in ArmA3, SCUBA ops are provided with a realistic scenery, sadly you are not able to do much under water other than using your weapons or pre-defined actions (thus only scripted actions).  Also the AI still gets stuck in buildings and behaves erratic under fire sometimes, i am pretty sure there will be mods to fix that though.  Well to finish this review: I just go this 2 days ago and i already feel i will be addicted to this masterpiece for quite a while (check it: 24 hours spent in game already), if you're one of the oldschool players who turned their back on ArmA after the last 2 releases: You MUST get this, you simply MUST. Trust me.

UPD: FPS tanks when fired upon, this is ♥♥♥♥ing unplayable.  There you go, saving and loading now works fine with ACE3. Now I can go with an actual review.  The game suffers horribly from lack of content and weak campaign. The DLC barely add anything yet they require ~$30 for at least Helicopters and Marksmen. Both DLCs add a few choppers and sniper rifles that should have been in the base game in the first place. But Bohemia decided to follow the extremely anti-consumer trend and ads for these DLCs pop up everywhere in the game. I can forgive Karts, they're cheap and actually add more than Helicopters and Marksmen. Now Apex, on the other hand, is an actual Expansion Pack, adding a new map, a new campaign, new stuff everywhere. And the funny thing is that Apex is only a little more expensive than Helicopters and Marksmen. Care for a price drop, Bohemia? I doubt it.  While OFP and Arma 2 were enjoyable without mods, Arma 3 was clearly developed with mods as life support in mind. You will not enjoy Arma 3 without mods. There's only a little bit of content for BLUFOR and OPFOR which absolutely need an expansion through various mods - you will get tired fairly quickly from the same guns and vehicles.  The campaign was abysmal even in comparison to campaigns from Arma 2 Expansions. Characters abruptly killed off, characters dissappearing from the story until the very last mission, a story-critical McGuffin appearing at the very same mission, no explanations at all, et cetera, et cetera. And yes, the campaign itself also abruptly ends.  Now to the good side. The controls are a bit smoother than Arma 2 - I particularly like the combat pace and simple bipod resting. The aiming is improved - now you can actually zoom into an RCO and not go into another screen. Sway is debatable, but it's more realistic, so I don't mind it most of the time. The new maps are quite big and nice. The graphics are great and the optimization at the time of writing this review isn't that bad when we talk about Bohemia. The original OFP music cues are back with a vengeance, they got amazing remixes.  But in the end, I cannot recommend you this game at full price with its amount of problems. I'd suggest that you buy this if Arma 3 + Apex would be $60. But the base game does not worth it at all, better stick to Arma 2 until it gets on sale. That's what I did, but I still kinda regret buying it.  Either way, DO NOT EVER BUY the DLCs unless they go -90% at a Steam Sale or something.

After playing this game for just near 3,000 hours, I think I can write a review. The way I'm going to do this is give you my overview, then I will break the game down into pros and cons. If you want to skip to the pros and cons of this game just scroll down a bit.  Overview: I have always wanted to play a game that encompassed the feel of war, many games these days make war seem much more fast paced than It really is. ArmA 3 takes its time in creating an environment that turns hours into week long deployments. If you are wanting a realistic hardcore simulator, without the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t this is your game.  THE CONS   Clipping is bad, you can just crawl through some walls by running and pressing 'z'.   Player base is mostly toxic.   Horribly Optimized.   Steep Learning Curve.   Bad Campaign.   Lack of direction after completing the game.   Horribly Optimized. (x2)  THE PROS   Beautiful Graphics   Player base (with external units) is generally accepting and kind.   Plethora of game modes.   Great community mods.   Realism.   Depth of combat.   Precision of military recreation.   Active Development.   New DLC launching all the time.   Community focused development team.   Generally a good game.  CONCLUSION  This game is a must have if you are interested in a large scale military sandbox. The multiplayer is amazing and the campaign, whilst bad, is still bearable. If you are on the fence about purchasing this game, do it. I recommend joining a unit, this will give you a group to help learn and master the game. Although if you do not have the best CPU on the market, i3-i7, you will not be getting the usual fps you would expect from an older PC game. Expect 30-60, depending on the areas of the map you are in!  I rate this game... 8/10, due to optimization being horrible.

Buildings are only 50% enterable compared to 99.9% of Altis a huge step backwards in map design and execution.  Whilst there are new factions, weapons and vehicles there are still no women in the Arma 3 world!  Would i still recommend Arma 3, hell yes! Would I buy the expansion version? Harder to answer in the positive, but if on offer and within your budget it would be good to have the new map and units and vehicles and weapons to access despite the expansion's other failings. From casual dicking around, to hardcore roleplaying and milsim and everything in between. Theres almost no other game like Arma. It's huge sandbox is capable of most anything you can imagine. It's realistic ballistics are incredible and one of the best features of the game. It's ability to be modded allows the modding community to provide you with always varied gameplay. All of these features and many more are the reasons Arma is one of my most favorite games and the game I think I've ever played the most of.    Arma is also incredibly demanding in several aspects. The most important of which is hardware. Even a gaming PC that can play most other games on ultra without missing a beat, May still have trouble with this game. This game is considerably CPU intensive. Stick with intel processors over AMD processors. Even on Standard to High settings my OC'd FX-8350 4.8GHz CPU and GTX 770 has trouble getting a consistent 30 fps on highly populated servers.

If you're looking for a game review you've come to the wrong place. But if youre looking for a fantastic ravioli recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients - To Make the Dough 375 grams (3 cups) plain flour 1/2 teaspoon salt 2 eggs 1/4 cup (50 ml / 3½ tablespoons) olive oil 1/2 cup (120 ml / 8 tablespoons) water Extra flour for dusting    - To Make Cheese Filling 15 ounces (425 grams) container Ricotta cheese 5 ounces (142 g/about 1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons) '3 Cheese Italian Blend' (Parmesan, Romano & Asiago) Note: grate these cheeses yourself and create your own custom blend. 1/2 cup cheddar cheese 2 eggs, lightly beaten 1/2 teaspoon salt 1/2 teaspoon pepper   - Extras Your favorite sauce for the ravioli (i.e. marinara/ marijuana) Parmesan cheese Basil Fried vegetables Shrimp Fish slices Chicken pieces  Make the Ravioli filling.  - In a small mixing bowl, add the ricotta and mash with a fork. - Add in the 3-cheese blend, Cheddar cheese, eggs, salt, and pepper. - Mix all ingredients thoroughly until you have a smooth, paste-like consistency. - Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and place it in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes.   Make the Ravioli dough.  - Crack eggs into a large mixing bowl and beat them with a fork. Add water, oil, and salt. Mix. - Add 1 cup flour to the bowl. Use a fork to mix the flour with the eggs, water, oil, and salt. Repeat with the rest of the flour. Mix until a smooth dough is formed. - Clear and clean off a large work surface and dust it with flour. This is where you are going to roll out your dough. - Take the dough out of the mixing bowl, shape it into a ball, and place it on your work surface. Knead for at least 10 minutes or until it becomes elastic. - Dust a rolling pin with flour to prevent the dough from sticking. Roll out the dough until it is about 1/8 inch (1/3 cm) thick, or about the thickness of 2 stacked quarters. - With a cookie cutter or upside-down water glass, cut out circles in the dough (will make about 15-20 dough circles). - Ball up the unused dough and either roll it out and make a couple more raviolis, or wrap it and put in the freezer for another time. Dough can keep for weeks when frozen. Just make sure to wrap well so that it doesn’t suffer from freezer burn or absorb freezer odor.   Fill the Ravioli shells.  - Take the ravioli filling out of the refrigerator and place a tablespoon of it in middle of a dough. - Fill a small bowl with water, dip your fingers in, and moisten around the outer edge of the dough circle. - Fold the dough in half over the filling, making a half-moon shape. Be sure all the filling stays inside. Pinch the edges together and then seal the edges of the ravioli with a fork. Make sure to press firmly and go all the way around. This will add a “homemade” touch as well. - Repeat this process for all your dough circles. - Dust the finished ravioli with flour to keep them from sticking together.   Form the Shells and Fill Using a Ravioli maker.  - Roll the dough into two sheets - Place one sheet on the ravioli maker, and form the filling cups. - Fill with the ravioli mixture. - Lay the second sheet of dough on top, and roll it out. This will seal in the filling. - Remove and separate the finished raviolis.  Cook the Ravioli.  - Fill a large pot with water and bring to a boil. - Place the ravioli in boiling water for 5-6 minutes, or until they float. You can also test for doneness by nibbling on the edges to test. - If you don't want to make all the ravioli at one time, you can freeze the rest  - Take ravioli out of boiling water with large slotted spoon and place on warmed plates  Serve it up. Top with your favorite sauce, grate some fresh cheese over it, and enjoy!
